body:
Due to Travis' [billing changes](https://blog.travis-ci.com/2020-11-02-travis-ci-new-billing), our CI is no longer sustainable on Travis.

We're attempting to replace our Travis usage with GitHub Actions, but things will be a little rocky in the interim.

Below is the progress on transitioning away from Travis.  Although much of this was coordinated from the neovim/bot-ci repo before, I think it may make sense to move some of this into the respective repository (e.g., nightly builds running from neovim/neovim).

- [ ] PR checks
  - [x] ASAN (https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/13287)
  - [x] TSAN (https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/13297)
  - [x] Lint (https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/13287)
  - [x] Windows (https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/13540)
  - [x] macOS (https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/13373)
  - [ ] Coverage
  - [x] Lua functionaltest (https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/14942)
  - [x] `-funsigned-char` testing (https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/18444)
  - [ ] 32-bit build
  - [x] Big-endian build https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/25862
- [x] Nightly builds
  - [x] Linux
    - [x] Tarball (https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/13445)
    - [x] Appimage (https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/13452)
  - [x] macOS (https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/13445)
  - [x] Windows (https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/13650)
- [x] ~Snap~ (https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/13312#issuecomment-922329101)
- [x] Reports
  - [x] PVS-Studio (https://github.com/neovim/doc/pull/6)
  - [x] clang-scan (https://github.com/neovim/doc/pull/4)
  - [x] Lint (https://github.com/neovim/doc/pull/4)
  - [x] vimpatch (https://github.com/neovim/doc/pull/6)
- [x] Auto label PRs (https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/14574)
- [x] neovim.io documentation (https://github.com/neovim/doc/pull/8)
- [x] neovim/deps updates (https://github.com/neovim/deps/pull/10)
- [x] Automatic PRs for version.c (https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/14160)
- [x] Sync deps (used for [unstable PPA](https://launchpad.net/~neovim-ppa/+archive/ubuntu/unstable))
- [x] Sync neovim mirrors https://github.com/neovim/libvterm/pull/8
- [x] Coverity (https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/14493)

comment_data.body:
I'd like to unblock nightlies, as they're causing a bit of a mess for plugins that track the bleeding edge. Are there likely to be any blockers beyond porting the steps to github actions?

cc @jamessan

> I'd like to unblock nightlies, as they're causing a bit of a mess for plugins that track the bleeding edge.

I've been putting together a workflow for nightly builds.  I hope to have a PR ready for it in the next day or two to at least update the Linux/macOS nightly.  Since we're still having issues getting the Windows GHA builds going, I hadn't looked into that yet.  Might need to port the code we have to get the artifact from appveyor.

> I hope to have a PR ready for it in the next day or two to at least update the Linux/macOS nightly.

Merged a PR to publish the linux/macOS tarballs.  Need to wait for it to trigger to see if it actually works, but assuming it does I'll work on including the appimage next.

macOS binaries seem to work for me. https://twitter.com/mitchhanberg/status/1335992614340997128?s=20

Thanks for your work on this!
Choco install neovim --pre and Choco upgrade neovim --pre don't work
@G-Ewing according to the issue description, nightly builds for windows haven't been completed yet, so it makes sense that choco installs don't work yet.
Anybody with windows nightly binaries?

> "Anybody with windows nightly binaries?"

@Borwe, I created a project, [neovim-windows-nightly](https://github.com/dstein64/neovim-windows-nightly), that uses GitHub Actions to build Neovim for Windows each night, based on the build instructions from [here](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/wiki/Building-Neovim#windows--msys2mingw).

This is intended as a temporary unofficial workaround until the Neovim official Windows nightly builds become available again.

Here's a link to the current build, which is the only build at the moment:
https://github.com/dstein64/neovim-windows-nightly/releases/download/nightly-2020-12-31T01.50.58.3070020%2B00.00/nvim-win64.zip

Updates will be posted automatically on the Releases page:
https://github.com/dstein64/neovim-windows-nightly/releases

And now official nightly builds are back 👍

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases/tag/nightly

https://launchpad.net/~neovim-ppa/+archive/ubuntu/unstable has old builds also. 

Are appimage and tarball the only officially supported formats? I'm wondering if the PPA is maintained by someone else. 
I'm asking because the PPA is not in the checkbox list in the OP so wanted to make sure
The PPA is unofficial, but I'm involved in that too. I'll take a look.
Changed how we mirror the neovim/neovim and neovim/deps repos to Launchpad, so that Launchpad pulls instead of requiring us to push from CI.  The unstable PPA is running again.
Did nightlies disappear on build-failure with the old pipeline? On a few occasions now I've had the 0.5 releases 404 on me. I don't recall that happening in the past, but that could be coincidental.

Is it just me or the nightly build is gone from the releases page? 🤔 

Edit: looks like the publish step failed https://github.com/neovim/neovim/runs/1686163254?check_suite_focus=true better luck tomorrow I guess 😅

> "better luck tomorrow I guess"

@richin13, if you're looking for the Neovim nightly build corresponding to that run (January 12, 2021), it appears that the artifacts were successfully generated (prior to the publish step failing) and available for download:
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/actions/runs/479467249#artifacts

The artifacts are also available for prior runs. For example, here's a link to the run from one day earlier (January 11, 2021), which ran successfully and has its artifacts available for download:
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/actions/runs/476820575

> > "better luck tomorrow I guess"
> 
> @richin13, if you're looking for the Neovim nightly build corresponding to that run (January 12, 2021), it appears that the artifacts were successfully generated (prior to the publish step failing) and available for download:
> [neovim/neovim/actions/runs/479467249#artifacts](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/actions/runs/479467249#artifacts)
> 
> The artifacts are also available for prior runs. For example, here's a link to the run from one day earlier (January 11, 2021), which ran successfully and has its artifacts available for download:
> [neovim/neovim/actions/runs/476820575](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/actions/runs/476820575)

@dstein64 gotcha! I use asdf-neovim though so looking for the artifact somewhere else might require some extra tweaking. I'll just wait to tomorrow as it seems that these failures are random

Unstable ppa is broken right now, because of: https://github.com/nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter/issues/994#issuecomment-798898704

Local build with 0ab88c2ea80caa7cda97b3a8479d0d32e4636ab6 works fine.

> Snap

- _something_ is pushing to the "edge" channel of https://snapcraft.io/nvim , assuming it's snapcraft's own CI.
- https://github.com/neovim/neovim-snap doesn't have any GHA setup
- Don't see any "snap" stuff in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/tree/master/.github/workflows

> > Snap
> 
>     * _something_ is pushing to the "edge" channel of https://snapcraft.io/nvim , assuming it's snapcraft's own CI.
> 
>     * https://github.com/neovim/neovim-snap doesn't have any GHA setup
> 
>     * Don't see any "snap" stuff in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/tree/master/.github/workflows

Travis was the only service set to trigger builds. I have no clue how new releases are being triggered

> Sync neovim mirrors

Addressed by https://github.com/neovim/libvterm/pull/8
I wonder if we should stop explicitly supporting 32-bit systems, and skip testing 32-bit. I get the impression it's not that common anymore and that we can deprioritize it.

I think that is sensible as 32bit has been put to pasture.

On Wed, Nov 8, 2023 at 7:18 AM dundargoc ***@***.***> wrote:

> I wonder if we should stop explicitly supporting 32-bit systems, and skip
> testing 32-bit. I get the impression it's not that common anymore and that
> we can deprioritize it.
>
> —
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/13312#issuecomment-1801981452>,
> or unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ABMJBTMCQ7S6DCVEA7COHN3YDOICJAVCNFSM4TZMBPA2U5DIOJSWCZC7NNSXTN2JONZXKZKDN5WW2ZLOOQ5TCOBQGE4TQMJUGUZA>
> .
> You are receiving this because you commented.Message ID:
> ***@***.***>
>

3/9 of Debian's official architectures are 32-bit. 4/6 of the unofficial architectures are 32-bit.  Avoiding regressions there would certainly be helpful to me.  Just not testing doesn't avoid the problems.

> Just not testing doesn't avoid the problems.

At the risk of sounding pedantic: that depends on what problems you want to solve. If it is to minimize 32-bit bugs then yes. If it is to maximimize maintainability and providing the best product for as many people as possible then the answer is not so black and white in my opinion.

I'd also like to emphasize that we are not Debian. We don't have seemingly infinite resources to test architectures barely anyone uses as a flex.

> If it is to maximimize maintainability and providing the best product for as many people as possible then the answer is not so black and white in my opinion.

Agreed, so finding bugs earlier is better.  Every time a distributor finds a bug that wasn't found in CI, that's a problem IMO.

32-bit is a lot easier to test than big-endian, but issues in either are latent bugs.

Whatever the decision, it should be clear.
What should be clear?

I don't really understand your point about distributors finding a bug to be a problem, are we supposed to test against all architectures that neovim *might* be used on? Again, this is not realistic nor feasible.
Accidentally closed the issue, reopened. Don't use vim motions on the browser kids.
Ugh fine, if you want 32bit testing so bad then let's go for it, but you'll have to help me fix the failing tests.

labels.description: automation for build, test, and release
labels.name: ci

title: CI: move to GitHub Actions, eliminate travis.yml
